channel.title: Frederick Boehm's Website
channel.description: Recent content on Frederick Boehm's Website

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Short courses and workshops Data Carpentry Social Sciences January 25-26, 2019, Arlington, Virginia, USA Data Carpentry Genomics September 15-16, 2018, Rolla, Missouri, USA Preparing to teach statistics (instructor) Spring 2018 Topic models for computational text analysis Summer 2016, Fall 2013 Formal courses Educating a diverse nation (co-facilitator) Spring 2017 (in-person) & Fall 2017 (online) Introductory statistics (instructor of record) Fall 2016, Spring 2016, Fall 2015, Summer 2015, Spring 2015, Fall 2014, Spring 2014

item.title: Software
item.description: qtl2pleio: Testing pleiotropy vs. separate QTL in multiparental populations gemma2: Multivariate random effects for genetics studies

item.title: Publications
item.description: Peer-reviewed journal articles Tauchman, E. C, F. J. Boehm and J. G. DeLuca (2015). “Stable kinetochore-microtubule attachment is sufficient to silence the spindle assembly checkpoint in human cells”.

item.title: Presentations
item.description: International Mammalian Genome Conference, November 11-14, 2018, Rio Mar, Puerto Rico Winner of best poster award Joint Statistical Meetings, August 1, 2018, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada

item.title: World-wide Web and Social Media
item.description: I’ve followed a series of blog posts from Cal Newport at http://calnewport.com/blog/ (with posts like this) in which Newport criticizes social media platforms for, among other things, limiting the scope of internet browsing.

item.title: R package site incorporation into my personal website
item.description: Overview I’ve been developing the R package qtl2pleio. It’s now at a stage where others can use it. I recently found the R package pkgdown, which allows developers to build, in an automated fashion, websites for their packages.

item.title: reticulate R package & Travis
item.description: I like to use Travis CI with my R packages. I recently wrote a R package, limmbo2, that is a wrapper for the python module limmbo.

item.title: limmbo2 R package now on Github
item.description: I have posted to Github the R package limmbo2. limmbo2 is a R wrapper to the freely available python module limmbo. I mention my interest in limmbo in an earlier blog post, so I won’t repeat it here.

item.title: Getting started with the reticulate R package
item.description: Motivation My colleague Rene Welch brought to my attention a recent pre-print, “LiMMBo: a simple, scalable approach for linear mixed models in high-dimensional genetic association studies” by Hannah Meyer, Francesco Casale, Oliver Stegle, and Ewan Birney.

item.title: Joan Didion’s "On self-respect"
item.description: Yesterday I read for the first time Joan Didion’s essay “On self-respect” in her 1968 collection of essays “Slouching towards Bethlehem”. “On self-respect” originally appeared in Vogue in 1961.

item.title: pkgdown R package for generating package websites on Github
item.description: I recently learned about the R package, pkgdown, an R package that provides functions that make it easy to build a website from an R package on Github.

item.title: Mathematical Writing by Donald Knuth, Tracy Larrabee, and Paul Roberts
item.description: I recently applied for a peer review training program that the Genetics Society of America organizes. An advisor kindly agreed to write a recommendation for my application.

item.title: John Roberts's Commencement Address
item.description: This afternoon, while listening to “All Things Considered” on Wisconsin Public Radio, I heard an excerpt from John Roberts’s recent commencement address. Here is the story from “All Things Considered”.

item.title: Getting started with blogdown
item.description: While browsing the internet, I stumbled upon Rstudio’s new package blogdown. I read posts from Karl Broman and found the the book that the package author - Yihui Xie - freely shares.
